videos.title: 2025 UCI gravel Turnhout - snelste gravelrace ooit (40km/u): van 20km solo naar crash met breuken!
videos.description:
🚀De snelste gravelwedstrijd ooit!? Met een gemiddelde snelheid van maar liefst 40km/u was de UCI gravel world series in Turnhout een waar spektakel.🔥Die @TufoTyres blijven verbazen 💯🤩

Zelf reed ik 20km solo aan de leiding, maar mijn race eindigde abrupt na 90km... 💥
Tegen zeer hoge snelheid knalde ik vol tegen een paal. De kopgroep raasde door het stof, en waarschuwingen voor obstakels bereikten de achterste renners niet. Het zicht was beperkt en voor ik het wist, lag ik tegen de grond!
Gelukkig zat er een stootkussen rond de paal, maar de impact was enorm.

Het resultaat? 🥹 Mijn fiets op 3 plaatsen gebroken en een lichaam dat nog steeds in shock is. Geen breuken bij mij, het herstel is begonnen.🙏💪

🚲Wil jij zien hoe deze krankzinnige gravelkoers verliep? Check de video en beleef het mee!📹

00:00 Trailer
00:44 Intro + startvak
04:16 Race deel 1
19:25 Solo Attack
26:10 Race deel 2
31:37 Crash
33:12 Recap + outro

⚡Like, deel en abonneer als je van high-speed gravel racing houdt en om mijn nieuwe avonturen samen viraal te maken! 

Als je van high-speed gravel racing houdt
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=VWvCYrDMuqI&list=PLrobrvh0PS8dsjAbnveAcO5NGYQzF02wH&index=2&t=12s

#UCIgravelworldseries #gravelracing #cyclinglife #crash #turnhout #bolero #cyclinglife

videos.title: TURNHOUT UCI GRAVEL RACE 2025
videos.description:
2 hours on board during Turnhout UCI GRAVEL RACE 2025 (Age group 35/39) 

32nd/321 finish - QUALIFY FOR WORLD CHAMPIONSHIP

Rider : Alexandre DAVID @topzouille (Instagram)
@teamlagodasse and @no_name_gravelrace.cc
Bike : SCOTT ADDICT RC GRAVEL CUSTOM

videos.title: FASTEST UCI Gravel Race EVER!? - UCI Turnhout Gravel
videos.description:
10% OFF Insta360 Go S3 + FREE carry case👉  https://www.insta360.com/sal/go-3s?utm_term=INR47RE 
This is Turnhout Gravel, the fastest UCI gravel world series race I've ever done and I lined up with one clear goal: to win! But, I made 3 big mistakes that made this race a lot harder that it already was. One of the most important factors in Gravel races are tires and bike setup and I'll go over the details of my bike setup in this video. Also I'm breaking down this intense gravel race and show all the action, close competition, and the end that put me down.

►I'm using the Insta360 Ace Pro 2 Camera to film my races, check here 👉 https://www.insta360.com/sal/ace-pro-2?utm_term=INR47RE
►My bike: YOELEO G21, 10% Discount with code cyclingfanatics 👉 https://www.yoeleoeurope.com/ or 👉 https://www.yoeleobike.com/?ref=cycli...

CHANNEL PARTNERS:

► Insta360 Camera 👉 https://www.insta360.com/sal/ace-pro-2?utm_term=INR47RE
► YOELEO BIKE/WHEELS 10% Discount with code cyclingfanatics 👉 https://www.yoeleoeurope.com/ or 👉 https://www.yoeleobike.com/?ref=cycli...
► OPTIMIZE chain wax,  👉 https://www.optimize.bike/?ref=jasper

► Nova2Ride OSPW 10% off code "cyclingfanatics" 👉 https://bit.ly/novaRide

Other channel partners:

Business inquiries (only): jasperverkuijl@gmail.com

videos.transcript:
What's up, guys? What's up, cycling
fanatics? This was the fastest UCI
gravel race I've ever done, and I lined
up with one clear goal to win.
>> We got a monster gap to close right now.
There's one guy away somewhere up the
road.
>> But three mistakes made it very hard to
reach my goal. From a rookie mistake at
the start line to the wrong tire choice
to a crash that ended my day.
Oh, this is Turnout Gravel, the first
UCI Worlds qualifier of the year. And
the first mistake I made came
immediately at the start. The good thing
was that I was there on time before the
whole crowd arrived. So, I lined up
pretty much at the front row. Finally, I
didn't have to chase all the way from
the back of the start box. But when the
group in front of us rolled off, I
thought I had 2 minutes until we would
start. So, I stepped off the bike for
some reason to calibrate my power meter
right when the gun went. I don't know
why. I was waiting there for an hour
doing nothing. Anyway, I jumped on the
bike, turned on the camera trying to
start my head unit, which was still
stuck like very deep in the calibration
menu. Big rookie mistake, guys. Get
ready and be ready to go full gas at the
start because these starts are like a
swift race. Luckily, I managed to get
back on the bike very quick and at the
front to get a good position ready for
the first gravel. For me, qualifying
itself isn't really the challenge. Just
finishing in the top 25% of my age
group, which qualifies you for the World
Championship, is actually pretty easy to
accomplish. The real goal here is
winning the qualifier because only the
winner gets a crucial advantage, a spot
in the priority start box at the World
Championship. Last year, as you've seen
in my video, I had to start all the way
in the back, fighting through the field,
burning all of my matches, and this
drastically lowered my chance to win.
And that's why in this season,
everything is about that front row
start. By the way, today's video is
sponsored by Insta 360. I filmed this
race with the Ace Pro 2 on my invisible
chest mount, and I also had a Go 3S in
the rear to capture all of the chaos.
The A2 has better battery life, better
audio, and a wider angle compared to the
older Hro One. The difference in angle
of view is pretty clear in a comparison
here with the Hro One. I'll go over my
setup and camera details later in this
video, but if you want to check out
Insta 360, the link is down below in the
description and top comment. The race
course of today was 144 km over two
loops with only 200 m of total
elevation, flat as a pancake. And for a
bigger rider, flat and fast racers are
in my favor. So that's why I was aiming
high today. On paper, it looked super
fast and it was. But what I didn't
realize beforehand, the many loose sandy
sectors, they would decide everything.
So, 2 minutes in and we're going onto
the first gravel. This is a very long
straight line. You can see it on the map
display at the top left. Speeds are
super high and until now I'm trying to
save energy and draft. And immediately,
we're overtaking riders from the earlier
group. And navigating through the chaos
begins here. It's super crucial to keep
an eye on the front riders of my
category because it's easy to lose them
riding through hundreds of other age
groupers. Now that I started at the
front, I can at least try to keep an eye
on these riders and not let anybody slip
away because that's the main goal here.
Stay in the front. 45k an hour here on
the gravel. This gravel is still pretty
smooth. So, the speeds are high, but
it's so crowded. So, it's actually
pretty difficult to get around all these
guys because there's not a lot of room
left on the road.
So, here we are 5 minutes in the race
and this is why it's so tricky. There's
a small gap in front of me. it opens up,
but it doesn't look like it because
there's so many scattered riders of the
1934 age group all over the place. And I
stay patient because I don't want to
close all the gaps myself. However, this
is also very, very dangerous. Some guys
will be gone before you know it,
especially with these small barriers or
tight turns. And if the group stretches
out, if they are 50 riders ahead, this
can be a couple hundred meters before
you know it. And at this point, I
couldn't really see the other guys. I
wasn't really happy. Here's my race
buddy Don in front of me with the baner
jersey, and he hammers it. He's going
around a lot of these riders. So, I stay
in his wheel and he's closing the gap to
the front. Then, that's how fast it can
go. I mean, I was still trucking along
with 45k an hour, but within the first
couple minutes, you could already lose
the front just like that. So, just to
make this clear, guys, I'm in the 34 39
age group. were racing with the pink
numbers. All the guys in the white
numbers are either elite or they're in
the 1934 age group. So, they are a
different category.
[Music]
We're constantly zigzagging and slowing
around other riders and it's difficult
because other guys are overtaking. So, I
can't do anything else but to overtake
as well, or I'm just going to be left
behind. You can never ride your own line
like this. I'm constantly riding out of
the ideal line, next to the trail, next
to the single track or whatever, going
over bumps and tree roots and
everything. It makes it super hard and
it's never easy. It's always on the gas.
So, until now, I think I've got sight on
all the other guys in my category. and
then left hand turn and that's when we
hit the first bit of very loose sand. My
bike is already breaking out all over
the place. Until now, I was still pretty
happy with my tire choice, but this this
was beginning of mistake number two. So,
even though there's bits and pieces of
bricks and tarmac, most of it was
off-road and stuff like this, it is
actually very, very bumpy. And like I
said before, a lot of riders are on the
right side here. I have to ride off the
ideal line and I'm just bumping and
stomping away. You can It's hard to see
on the footage, but it was so bumpy and
now I'm kind of stuck. Uh nowhere to go.
Other guys of my category are in the
front. So I'm just trying to find a way
to overtake some of these guys again not
to get left behind. It can go quick,
guys.
All of a sudden, Porco is there on the
left on the other side of the water. How
the hell did he get there? That's pure
track knowledge. And if you never
pre-raced this track before, you would
never be there. But, uh, he was
overtaking a lot of riders. And now I
think he is the first rider in that
group. So paying attention, paying
attention and paying attention.
So, here we riding through a very big
group of 1934 riders and we're
approaching the front of them. And this
is where things get a bit messy. These
guys are racing their own race, but they
don't seem to notice that we are a
different age group. One of the riders
is even taking his hands off the bars to
shove me aside. So, I just said, "Dude,
keep your hands on the bars. What are
you doing? I already made up 2 minutes
on you." And then he starts laughing.
Which is actually funny because he
doesn't even realize we're a different
group and we already caught up with them
and we're overtaking them. Whatever.
This happens all the time and it's the
worst part of these mixed categories
racing. Guys, if you're watching this
and you're racing in these events, don't
latch on to every rider flying by from
another category. There's usually a
whole line of us. Just give some space.
Focus on your own race and battle the
riders in your group. We are going to
catch up and we're going to pass. So,
please give some space.
Driving the pace here again, closing in
on another huge group of 1934 riders,
which means the whole slam circus is
going to start over again.
All right, guys. Let's switch on the
rear camera. It's the Insta Go 3S. the
smallest camera I have. It's only 39 g
and it fits very well underneath the
saddle. I didn't use it all race because
the battery life is limited, but this
second view perspective is really cool
and the 4K quality out of this super
small camera is actually impressive.
Blue segment coming up. These parts are
super super important and decisive for
this race. So staying at the front is of
utmost importance. And I'm at the very
front of our category right now. Fabio
is coming on my right. He's taking the
inside line. And I was forced onto the
outside. There's gates here in the
middle of the road. Super dangerous. And
then right in front of me,
a crash.
I was exactly stuck behind these riders.
So I try to go around as quickly as I
can get back up to speed. But at this
point, I couldn't tell who was ahead of
me. I kind of missed that. So I assumed
some of my category avoided the crash
and were up the road. So again, full gas
to chase.
Right now, I'm passing down here on my
right. I'm yelling at him so he can jump
on my wheel, but it looks like he's
already on the limit and didn't have
enough power left. You can see how tough
these sand parts are and why it's so
important to be in the front and also
why it's so important to have the
correct tires. Just hammering right now.
500 watts through the loose sand. You
can see other guys are on the on the
right hand side trying to, you know, get
that little bit of hard line. Uh, but
then it's very bumpy in the grass. So,
it's also not ideal. However, I'm trying
to get behind one of these guys to get a
little bit of draft as well. It's just
mayhem. It's everybody for himself. It's
almost like you're going uphill. You
can't really, you know, have that much
of an advantage by riding in a group.
Everybody has to push high power right
now. approaching another corner, taking
the inside, overtaking like 10 riders it
in one go, and then full gas out of the
corner again to accelerate. This is a
battle right now. It's full gas. If
you're in the front and manage to drop
other riders, that's where you can get
away from from your group. That's where
you make the difference. And by now, I
had realized my second mistake, my bike
setup. So, I'm racing on my Yolo G21.
This is the same bike that I used last
year. Yolio launched the new G21 Alira
recently and I'll be building that up
for my world championship.
Nice. For now though, I'm still on the
previous model. The main change that I
made for this bike in this race were the
wheels and tires. In gravel, the tire
setup is everything. The casing, the
width, and the pressure will decide your
grip, rolling resistance, and comfort.
In my Rule Championship video, I
explained why I usually run wider tires.
45 mm with a fast knobbyby thread.
>> One race on these tires, and it just
gives me so much more grip through
corners. So, I actually really like
them. And they're still very fast
because this the the knobbies are very
tight together in the middle of the
tire. So, but here I I kind of gambled.
Winning is the goal, not just finishing.
So sometimes you have to think outside
the box and take some risk. I didn't
recall the course, so I could only trust
on others saying it was smooth and very
fast like a racetrack. So that's why I
went for more narrow 38 mm semi slicks.
Even though there was some tarmac, the
gravel wasn't that smooth. It's actually
less smooth than it looks. I was running
quite low pressure, but not low enough.
And that can only be accomplished with
wider tires, which would have floated
over the sand way easier. So, at this
point, I realized that choosing your
tires to favor these key segments is way
more important than having faster tires
on the long stretches of tarmac. So,
what tires would you ride? Let me know
in the comments. Here we are back on the
road. So, I'm still a bit behind from
that crash and now I will try to catch
back up. So, of course, my narrow tires
may be a bit faster on this couple
minutes of tarmac and I'm closing in on
Vincent who's in my category, but I'm
still missing one guy, Fabio. he's up
the road and the longer it takes to
catch him back, the smaller the chance
will be as he will also be joining
faster riders of the 19 to 34 age group.
And as you can see behind me, there's a
massive gap and this is all a result of
both the crash and then the the very
hard segment with the loose sand because
that's where everything breaks up. So
you can see how fast it goes and how big
of a gap there was behind me, which I
sort of avoided by going full gas again
once I got around this crash.
Heat.
[Applause]
Oh, [ __ ]
These loose parts are brutal. It's like
having your finger in the door and it's
just, you know, squeezing your finger.
It's just not just physical. It's also
mentally you're grinding maximum effort
in a in a sector that you don't know how
long it's going to last. There's no
smooth line. There's no options. The
only thing you can do is just push. You
hope to find a hard line with less
resistance and you just keep on going.
>> Well, good luck with that.
>> Well, the other option is is to crack
and to drop and never see the front guys
again. At this moment, you can see my
heart rate. It's 176. I'm still pushing.
We're almost an hour in the race, so
fatigue is going to sort of accumulate.
It's going to get harder and harder. And
at this point, I I couldn't really
accelerate again. I couldn't close this
gap fast enough. So, I'm just trying to
push as hard as I can and not drop
behind. And I'm just I'm struggling. I'm
struggling so bad. The bike is going all
over the place because of this loose
sand. And by experience, I know big soft
tires will just go so smooth. So,
believe me, the biggest difference is
the tire pressure. And here we are on a
very narrow part through these trees
here, through these narrow barriers.
This time it was fine. But in the second
lap, uh, not so much. Spoiler alert. Um,
but there is a big gap in front of me,
which is not good. We have to close that
up. We're 35k in this race. 1 hour in.
We still have a long way to go.
>> Just over an hour in. 43 kilometers
done. We've got 100k left. Average speed
is close to 40 km an hour. That's really
fast for a gravel race. And I wanted to
keep on pushing because my goal is in
front of me, but not alone, not by
myself at the front. The way to do it is
to find a few strong guys to work with.
Often if a group gets too big, half of
them will just be drafting on the back,
do nothing. That's not what you want.
And at this moment, uh, we're still
riding for the second spot. I'm back
with Kevin and Vincent, but Fabio is
still ahead of us. And right now, we are
on this gravel and it looks really
smooth, but it's not. It's more like
little chunky rocks. I guess this will
come close to to sort of USA style of
gravel.
[ __ ] yeah.
>> And my tires, they actually dig in a
little bit and wire tires would have
more skimmed over these rocks. So, the

is causing a lot of drag, which will
cause a lot of energy. And another spot
where wider tires would have definitely
be faster. So, I finally spot Fabio far

in Belgium kit here in our group far far

[ __ ]
Come on.
At this moment, we're riding over this

It's just before start finish and it's

it definitely was not easy. Uh we're
still with with a group of 1934 guys.
Kevin is there and he hits it at the

he he goes off the gas for a little bit
for me to arrive.
>> Alle
is sort of my best friend. Kevin, he

suffering suffering very very bad. Like
I said, on the map it looks easy in a

us.
But there's one guy away somewhere up

Now look how bumpy this is. And I'm

I'm done, too. And this was technical
and track knowledge really mattered. For
example, here I didn't know to go right,

>> hitting a very, very [ __ ] line.
We approached start finish, and my
battery was dead, so I only got these
short flashes of video here, but I'm
going to swap my battery. People often

Kevin, and me are trying to break clear
of these big group of younger riders.
Without them, it was way less chaotic.

realistically,
number one is up the road somewhere with

in the bag. But grabbing that is harder

uphill.
